titleStmt.title: Crossing of proverbs The second part. With, Certaine briefe questions and answeres. By B.N. Gent.
Crossing of proverbs. Part 2

titleStmt.title: Crossing of proverbs The second part. With, Certaine briefe questions and answeres. By B.N. Gent.
Crossing of proverbs. Part 2
titleStmt.author: Breton, Nicholas, 1545?-1626?

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [By G. Eld] for Iohn Wright, and are to be solde at his shop without Newgate, at the signe of the Bible,

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: CROSSING OF PROVERBS. THE SECOND PART. WITH, Certaine briefe Questions and Answeres.
AT LONDON, Printed for Iohn Wright, and are to be solde at his Shop without Newgate, at the signe of the Bible. 1616.

div.head: The Second PART, OF Crossing of Prouerbs

sp.speaker: Prouerbs.
sp.p: EVery Trades-man knowes his owne ware.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not if his Female deceiue him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: More hast the worse speed.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in the hast, but lacke of heede.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee that hath his eyes in his head wil looke about him.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, he may be blindfolded and then he cannot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wanton kisses are the keyes of finne.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not except the diuell keep the lockes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Warre is the greatest dispoyling of a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, a Plague if it continue, may be greater.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Giue, gaue is a good fellow.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, hee is a Churle that hath no charity.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Loue is the peace of the Senses.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not where it is ioined with Ielousie.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Witty women are sweet Companions.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not, but when they are pleased, or else they are froward.

sp.speaker: Prou.
sp.p: Crabbed minds are pleased with nothing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for nothing can giue no pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Kind hearts are soonest wrong'd.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they be carefull.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no tree but beareth fruit.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, the Sic amour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: High waies are lawfull for Trauaylers.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they meet with theeues.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The greatest sort of fish keep the bottome.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for small Eeles keepe in the mudde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Too much of any thing is good for nothing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, what is good, is good for somthing.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wishers and woulders, are neuer good house-holders.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, a man may both wish wel and doe well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Taking of bribes is priuate theeuery.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for then there would be many hangd.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The teares of age are lamentable.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they drop from sore eyes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A merry Companion is a Wagon in the way.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so for if your iourney be long you may be weary for want of carriage.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee is a fond fisher that angles for a frogge.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not so, for hee may be a baite for a better fish.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When theeues fall out, true men come by their goods.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, Theeues may be hang'd, and true men ne're the better.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All offices are places of esteeme.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, not the Hang-mans.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is nothing so sure as death.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, life to the Faithfull.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Newes are like fish.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for then they would stinke when they are stale.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The Mistris Eye makes the Capon fatt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, it is the good cramming of them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Marriage is honourable.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when it is dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Children are the comfort of their Parents.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they proue vngratious.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No trust to a drie sticke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, that it will burne well.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A light supper makes cleane sheets.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, he that is loose in the hiltes, may make worke for the Launderesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hasty spirits neuer want woe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, when they are pleased.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: As the life is, so is the death.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for she that liued a Whore, may dye a Bawde.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Neate apparell graceth a man.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, a neate man graceth his apparell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Kindnesse deserues loue.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if it be common.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Poore vertue liues as dead.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in ihe eye of honour.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Couetuousnes corrupteth wealth.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, a noble minde is euer it selfe.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A faire woman is the trouble of wisdome.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, shee is the treasure of a true wit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hasty climbers haue sodaine falls.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they sit fast.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When the belly is full, the bones would be at rest.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
No, it is the spirit, not the bones:
for they haue no power of desire.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Try, and then trust.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for he that is kind to day, may be crosse to morrow.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Whensoeuer you see your friend, trust to your selfe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, when you cannot helpe your selfe without your friend.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is none so faithlesse as an Hereticke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, an Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He is a fond Chap-man that comes after the fayre.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, he may hap to buy better cheap in the market.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is a time allowed for all things.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, not to doe euill.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Honour is the reward of vertue.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, but where it is rightly giuen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sweet meate must haue sowere sauce.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, a good stomake needs it not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: When Sunday comes, it will be holyday.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not with Carriers, for they trauell all the weeke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A Coward is fearefull, without hyre.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for feare it selfe is full of hurt.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pouerty is the purgatory of reason.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, it is the tryall of patience.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He is wise that is rich.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, he is rich that is wise.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No misery to imprisonment.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, an vnquiet wife.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No comfort to liberty.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, a louing wife.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The night is the time of rest for all creatures.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not for Gamesters, that play night and day.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Learning is the labour of the braine.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, it is rather of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nothing so necessary for Trauallers as Languages.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, Money.

sp.speaker: Question.
sp.p: WHat is the best kinde of gouernment?

sp.speaker: Answere.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is most dangerous in a Kingdome?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ciuill Warre.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is most troublesome in a Common-wealth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sectes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What quarrell breeds the best war?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Religion.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What most displeaseth God?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Idolatry.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which is the best trauell, that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Towards heauen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the best king that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Dauid, for he was chosen to Gods owne heart.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Who was the greatest Conqueror that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Christ Iesus, for he conquered sinne, death and hell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the greatest foole that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Adam when he had lost Paradise for an Apple.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who had the greatest fall that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Lucifer, when hee fell from heauen to hell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the best wrestler that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Iacob, when he wrestled with the Angell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the wisest Queene that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Queene of Sheba, that came to Salomon for wisdome.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the foolishest King that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pharaoh, when he opposed himselfe against God.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the arrantest Traytor that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Iudas, when hee betrayed his Master Christ Iesus.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the best learning in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Truth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the greatest wealth in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the greatest ioy in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A cleere Conscience.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the greatest Vertue in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Patience.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the greatest blessing to Nature?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Health.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat is the most griefe in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Want.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which was the stoutest woman that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Iudith, when shee cut off Holofernes head.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which was the first mad-man that we reade of?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Saul, when he killed himselfe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was the most vnnaturall that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Caine, when he slew his brother Abel.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When was Noah layd naked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When he was drunke.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When did Lot commit incest?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When he was drunke.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When was Sampson ouerthrowne?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When he was a sleepe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When was Salomon led to Idolatry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When he followed strange women.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When began the curse on the Iewes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When they fell to Idolatry.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What state is the most quiet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The meane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What actions are most honorable?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That are honest.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What study is most profitable?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Law.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What Musique is sweet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The voyce.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where is the best beeing in the world,

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: where a man likes best.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the hinderance of content,

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Variety.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the substance of all earthly, creatues?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Vanity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the comfort of a blind man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That he shall see no vanities.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What comforteth a deafe man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That he shall heare no villanies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what comforteth a lame man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That he shall not be sent of hastye arands.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what of a dumbe man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That he shall not be called to Question for his tongue.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the comfort of Age?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That hee hath past the perils of his youth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What should be the care of youth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To giue honour to his age.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Why doe women weepe more then men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because they cannot haue their wils to gouerne.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the easiest life in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A Parasites, to feede vpon euery mans trencher.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What life is the most laboursome?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Study, for it spends the spirit, and weakens the body.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who is the best companion in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A Library, where a man talkes without offence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And where is the worst company?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In a Gaole, where there are few gracious.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the best Art in the World?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To gather wealth without wickednesse.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And which is the worst Art that euer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The blacke Art, for it brings the Student to Hell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How doth ease breed the Gout?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By lack of motion of the members.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the best meat in the world?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That which agreeth best with the stomack.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what the best drinke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That that breedes the best blood.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what is the best excercise?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The moderate.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ware is cheapest?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That which is had for thankes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What country is most fruitfull?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Where there is best ground.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When is it best to take Phisicke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In time of sicknes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When is it best to make meales?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the stomacke is empty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What sauce is the best?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hunger.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What flesh is best?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That which is sweet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What fish is the best?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That which is new taken.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which is the best lesson to thriue?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
To haue much, to spend little, and to
giue nothing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is a Plaister for all paines?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Patience.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what is a remedy for all diseases?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Death.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is a misers Musicke?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Chinking of money.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the honour of a man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: to be his words maister.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the true signe of a foole:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To be euer laughing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is good for the tooth-ache:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pull it out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat is good for the heart-ache:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Patience.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat is good for the itch:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Scratching.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhich is the worst worme in the world:

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The worme of conscience.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat is most necessary in a common wealth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Money.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat most vnnecessary?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Cardes

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Fortune fauours fooles.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, there are fooles enow, but there is no fortune.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Woemen are like Waspes in their anger.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for Waspes leaue their stings, but Women neuer leaue their tonges behind them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Virgins are Angel-like Creatures.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for then they would not bee so proud of their beauty.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Musicke is comfortable to the care.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when the braine is full of businesse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A good Huswife is a Iewell.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if she be a scold.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Good wine makes a merry heart,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when the Conscience is wounded.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The neerer the Church, the further from God.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not with the Religious.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Good wine needs no bush.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, for trauellers that know not the house.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Drunkennesse is counted good fellowship.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not, but among bad fellowes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The sunne shines through all the world,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, not in a close chest.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery Bird is knowne by his feather.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, Good-man Bird hath no feathers.

sp.speaker: P.,
sp.p: Painted creatures are dead speakers.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for then many women would be silent.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Wise men are at peace with all the world,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not with some women, for they will neuer be quiet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A Bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they be fast limed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Money is a great master in a Market.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, hee is a slaue to a Begger.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Money is a continuall Traueller in the world.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for with some hee is close prisoner.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery child knowes his owne father.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Not, but as his mother tels him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no paine like the Gowt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, the Tooth-ach.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery man knowes what is best for himselfe.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No not Mad-men.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Vsurers are alwaies good Husbands.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, they may be badde to their wiues.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Good ware makes quick markets.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, tis the money makes the speed.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Of idlenesse comes naught but ignorance.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, Beggery.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Oppression makes the wise man mad.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No wise men will be are oppressions.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is nothing stoln without hands.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, a good name with an ill tongue.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Rich men are Stewards for the poore.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, when the poore mens pence fill their purses.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Abuses shew the corruption of time.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, it is the Timers.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A Louse is a Beggers companion.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when hee is in the head of a Lord.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Beauty is a naturall blessing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in a painted woman.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Early vp and ne're the neere.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, he may haue a better stomacke to his dinner.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He that is warn'd is halfe arm'd.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for words make no Armour.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A shrew profitable, is good for a man reasonable.

sp.speaker: C
sp.p: Not so, the profit may bee good, but the Shrew is nought.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Two may keepe counsaile, if the third be away.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if a Woman be one.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee that is wise in his owne conceite, is a foole.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for hee that is wise is no foole.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: The Euening praiseth the day.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not so, tis he that notes it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Faire words pacifie wrath.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in dogged spirits.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ambition endangers life.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, tis the actions that followes it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A winde Instrument giues a sweete sound.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in the ease of the Chollick downwards.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The swelling of the belly signifies the dropsie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in women with child.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A Bagpipe makes more noyse then Musicke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for tis all musicke though not of the best.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no foole to the old foole.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, the young foole is a foole too as well as he.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery Bird hatcheth her owne egges.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so: the sparrow hatcheth the Cuckoes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: All Creatures are drowsie after Venerie.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, the Cocke crowes when hee hath trod his hen.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nothing is swifter then the winde.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes thought, that is at heauen in an instant.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nothing is more subtill then the Aire.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, the Diuell.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: He that handleth thornes will pricke his fingers.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if his Gloues be good.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is nothing brighter then the Diamond.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, the Sunne.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pouerty parts good company.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when Rich men part with enuy.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sicknes soakes the purse.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, tis the patient that is soak't, not the purse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hee that is borne to be drownd, shall neuer be hang'd.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, Pirats drowne hanging at Wapping.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Sicknes is the cause of death.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, for many dye that are not sicke.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A couetous man is neuer liberall.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, when hee giues all away at his death.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Tis merry when Gossips meet.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if they fall out vpon the reckoning.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: There is no fire without smoake.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes in a flint.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pearles are restoratiue.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, not the Pearle in the eye.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Religion is the rule of life.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not to an Athiest.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The law is costly.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, tis the Lawyer.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A short horse is soone curried,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if he be very foule.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A good horse that neuer stumbled,

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: No, there is no such Horse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Hard fare makes hungry stomackes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not among sicke folkes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Many handes make quicke worke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not among the Lazy.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A young Courtier an old begger.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if he be thrifty.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A good horse riddes ground apace.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if the way be full of holes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A staffe is soone found to beat a dogge withall.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not in a Plaine where there is no wood.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No extreame will hold long.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes, weakenesse in a Consumption.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Euery thing is as it is taken.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so, many things may bee taken amisse.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A foole is euer laughing.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not when hee is beaten, for then hee cryes.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Scoldes and infants neuer lin bawling.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes when they are asleepe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Bounce quoth the gun.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not so, Gunnes cannot speake.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Bate me an ase quoth Bolton.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: No, I wil not bate him an ase: wherfore should I?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Content is a kingdome in this world.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not so▪ for the world giues it not.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Mony makes friendes enemies.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Not so, it is the euill vse of it.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Neerer is my skin then my shitt.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not where the flesh is rawe:

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Nothing breakes the heart more then thought.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Yes a bullet.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Loue will goe through stone walls.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not til there be holes in them.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: One rotten sheepe will marre a whole flocke.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if the Shepheard looke well to them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Ouer shooes, ouer bootes.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not except wil ouer runne wit.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Lawyers are temporall Physicians, in helping weake Clyents

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Not if their Apothecaries bils bring their purses into a consumption.
